data.text: INDEX
Appendix 1: Preliminary Equality Analysis Appendix 2: Additional information
Appendix 3: How can essential oils be used? Appendix 4: Suggested / Example blends
Purpose

There is an increasing demand for the use of complementary therapies within the whole spectrum of the childbearing cycle and evidence has shown that clients are using aromatherapy on their own initiatives without the relevant knowledge and education to administer essential oils safely.

Aromatherapy and massage have been shown to provide benefits to clients in the antenatal, intrapartum and postnatal periods by the action of specific essential oils to perform various functions to enhance wellbeing in the childbearing cycle.
Aromatherapy is both a science and an art in which highly concentrated essential oils extracted from various parts of different plants are used for their therapeutic properties.

The use of Aromatherapy combined with massage in labour will offer another choice for mothers in the Midwife-led Units at Maldon, Braintree, and in the Co-Located Birth Unit at Broomfield or at home births. Labour Ward has not been included due to the fact that women who are pre-term may be using the delivery rooms.
Aromatherapy and massage offers relaxation and acts as an adjunct to enhance normal labour.

Only those Midwives who have received training from midwives who have undertaken the accredited course will be eligible to use aromatherapy massage in their practice to support mothers in a safe environment, selecting from a limited range of oils.

It should be noted that as aromatherapy is a complementary therapy and there is some evidence as to its efficacy, the Trust is not able to provide any assurance that women will experience the claimed benefits and the Trust will not be responsible in the event of lack of efficacy.
The Trust is not promoting Aromatherapy as an appropriate replacement for traditional analgesia/medicine.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 1)
Inclusion / Exclusion Criteria
Inclusion Criteria
Women who have been assessed, contraindications excluded, and have given verbal consent. Documentation of consent should be recorded in the maternity records.
Women who are at term with a normal pregnancy
Women in the latent phase of labour
Women in established labour
Women should be provided with sufficient information to make an informed decision about the use of aromatherapy oils and massage.
Midwives administering an essential oil massage are required to document the discussion together with their rationale in the maternity notes
Verbal consent is sufficient and women should be aware that they have the opportunity to decline without affecting subsequent care.
Exclusion Criteria:
Women who do not give their consent;
Antenatal women <37 weeks gestation;
Women being cared for by a pregnant midwife who is less than 36 weeks pregnant;
Women receiving care on Labour Ward;
Known allergy to any of the essential oils or carrier oils.
List of Essential Oils to be Used and their Storage
Oils available are as follows:
Bergamot – to help with analgesia, relief of fear and spasms, uplifting
Clary Sage – said to enhance uterine action, induction and acceleration, antibacterial
Grapefruit – said to be calming and help relieve fear and anxiety,
Lavender – said to relieve backache, sciatica, symphisis pubis pain, antibacterial
Frankincense- reduces pain, fear, anxiety, hyperventilation and panic attacks, is also a diuretic, antiseptic and expectorant
Mandarin- reduces muscle spasm, flatulence, constipation and anxiety also antiseptic, stimulant and sedative, hypnotic and invigorating
Spearmint- reduces nausea and vomiting, mental and physical fatigue and headaches
Carrier Oils
4.2.1 The carrier oil of choice will be Grapeseed Oil.
4.2.2 Oils will be purchased via procurement from the approved supplier Absolute Aromas.
4.2.3 Oils will be stored in a locked cupboard in the Midwife Led Birthing Units.
4.2.4 Oils brought in by women for their own use will not be allowed as purity and quality cannot be guaranteed.
Method of Application and Concentrations
The maximum numbers of oils allowed in one mix is  The mix can be decided by the individual midwife and is dependent on the desired effect and preferences of the woman.
Mixing and concentration:
To encourage labour after 40 weeks gestation / latent phase – 3% concentration;
Labour and postnatal – 2% concentration.
(Refer to the table below)
The numbers of drops refer to the total numbers - for example if mixing 3 oil combination with 15ml of Grapeseed oil in a 2% concentration (labour), the midwife can add:
2 drops of each oil A, B and C;
1 drop of oil A, 3 drops of oil B, 2 drops of oil C or any combination as long as the total number of drops does not exceed the recommended dose to quantity of carrier oil.
Massage – using the correct concentration of essential oil to carrier oil. Areas to massage include:
Back, shoulders;
Hands;
Feet.
Inhalation by using oils on tissue or gauze and placing on woman's chest or abdomen. In this case one drop of essential oil to be dropped directly onto tissue and inhaled regularly.
Oils are not to be added to the water in the birthing pool, where the baby is expected to be born, however women can still benefit by receiving a hand massage or for use in the bath.
Oils are not to be used on babies.
Avoid massaging directly over varicose veins
Safety
General rules:
Do not take essential oils internally;
Neat essential oils should not be used directly on skin;
Avoid contact with sensitive areas such as eyes, nose;
Wash hands thoroughly after massaging;
Keep essential oils away from naked flames;
Store correctly;
Pregnant staff in the first trimester should not inhale essential oils;
Pregnant staff who are less than 37 weeks pregnant should not use Clary Sage;
Any blends should be clearly labelled to avoid confusion;
All aromatherapy oils should be labelled when opened with date.
Dealing with adverse reactions
Wash skin with unperfumed soap to remove oil;
Expose skin to oil to encourage evaporation;
Complete a risk event form electronically via Datix Web.
Disposal of unused oil mixture
Any remaining oil should be wiped out of the dish using paper towels and disposed of in the clinical waste (yellow) bag;
Glass dishes should be washed thoroughly using hospital grade detergent, rinsed and dried;
Oils should not be given to a patient to take home because we do not stock appropriate dark glass containers to do so.

Administration: The NMC defines ‘medicinal products' as any substance or combination of substances which may be administered to human beings with a view to making a medical diagnosis or to restoring, correcting or modifying physiological functions is likewise considered a medicinal product. Therefore administration should be taken seriously and the following considered:
Identification of the patient;
Any known allergies;
The therapeutic uses of the oil, its recommended dosage, side effects, precautions and contraindications;
The plan of care;
The oils should be clearly labelled, in date and are of a high quality from the approved chosen supplier Absolute Aromas;
Appropriate dosage and method of administration.
Use of Diffusers
Fill the diffuser with water according to instructions, do not use carrier oil. Use up to 6 drops of essential oils into the water and switch on;
For use in single occupant rooms only, not recommended for patient use in shared areas;
Use intermittently and check with the patient if they are still happy to have the diffuser on regularly;
Diffusers must be emptied and cleaned using Hospec liquid detergent before and after each use to remove oils from the previous patient and to ensure water is not stagnant.
Staffing and Training
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to- date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy and the Maternity annual audit work plan. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.

The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group report will be reported to the Directorate Governance Meeting on a quarterly basis and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Quality and Safety Committee (PSQC) within the Chief Nurse report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.

Guideline monitors have been nominated to each clinical area to ensure a system whereby obsolete guidelines are archived and newly approved guidelines are now downloaded from the intranet and filed appropriately in the guideline folders. ‘Spot checks' are performed on all clinical guidelines quarterly.

Quarterly Clinical Practices group meetings are held to discuss ‘guidelines'. During this meeting the practice development midwife can highlight any areas for future training needs that will be met using methods such as ‘workshops' or to be included in future ‘skills and drills' mandatory training sessions.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued to all staff with embedded icons to highlight key changes in clinical practice to include a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly. Midwives that are on maternity leave or ‘bank' staff have letters sent to their home address to update them on current clinical changes.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.

Regular memos are posted on the guideline and audit notice boards in each clinical area to notify staff of the latest revised guidelines and how to access guidelines via the intranet or clinical guideline folders.
References
NMC (2015) The Code. Professional standards of practice and behaviour for nurses, midwives and nursing associates. London: NMC
Tiran D & Kenyon C (2009) Implementing Aromatherapy in Maternity Care: A training package for midwives and therapists.
Chummun H (2004) Complimentary Therapies to Reduce Physiological Stress in Pregnancy, Complimentary Therapies in Nursing and Midwifery, 10(3),
Pollard K R (2008) Introducing aromatherapy as a form of pain management into a delivery suite, Journal of the Association of Chartered Physiotherapists in Women's Health, 103, 12-16.
Woodman L & Davis. J (2018) Aromatherapy for Childbirth reference manual.

Royal College of Midwives (2014) Position statement: Complimentary therapies and natural remedies. London: RCM https://www.rcm.org.uk/sites/default/files/Complementary%20Therapies%20and%20Natu ral%20Remedies_3.pdf

Additional information

table_items.text: In aromatherapy essential oils are safely used externally in:
-Is the smell unappealing? -Any known sensitivities, allergies or reactions? to naturally perfumed products? -Is the uterus hyperstimulated? -Essential oils are for external use only
-Store essential oils in a dark locked cupboard; -Store in a marked box.

data.text: Appendix 3
How can essential oils be used?

table_items.text: 4 drops of essential oil go into a bowl of hot or cold water, depending on preference. Wring cloth/flannel out after soaking in the bowl and apply to areas of discomfort or tension. Compress can relieve muscular pain and headaches, using water also increases the action of essential oils.
1 or 2 drops of essential oil onto a paper fan to cool down and calm down. One drop of spearmint onto a paper fan is good for nausea.

Massage helps strengthen relationships within the birthing room, the caring touch of a birthing partner aids creating an environment to encourage normal birth. Massage can be used in areas such as back, shoulders, hands and feet. Use a 1% dilution for normal skin and a 0.5% dilution for sensitive skin. Massage should never be carried out on broken skin and oils should be washed off before entering the birthing pool.
1 drop of chosen essential oil on gauze swab / tissue or cotton wool to inhale the aroma. Maximum of 2 drops in total for a combination of 2.
Diffusers and aromastones can be used with up to 6 drops of essential oil. It is important to use intermittently and to regularly check if everyone within the room is happy for it to remain on.

Essential oils are not to be used in water where birth is expected i.e. the birthing pool. They can however be used in the bath, up to 6 drops can be used in the bath once it has been run and just before getting in. Essential oils can also be dropped onto a flannel (up to 2 drops) and rubbed briskly over the body on exiting the shower.

data.text: Appendix 4
Suggested / Example blends

table_items.text: Irregularity of contractions, discomfort & or fear
Anxiety and stress, lack of focus
Promotes uterine function, reduces irritation and panic
